clinical_study.brief_title: Goal Management Training in Individuals With PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder)
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Control Trial Examining the Treatment Efficacy of a Novel Approach to Cognitive Remediation in Individuals With Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder and Co-Morbid Conditions

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the effect of a manualized treatment (Goal Management Training, or GMT) on the cognitive impairments associated with PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) in certain populations. Participants will be randomized to either GMT group treatment (with or without use of a mindfulness meditation aid), or a wait-list condition.

detailed_description.textblock: PTSD has an emotional impact on individuals, but it is also associated with impaired cognitive functioning (e.g., memory, attention, executive functioning). This study is a randomized control trial for a cognitive remediation intervention (Goal Management Training, or GMT) that has been shown to improve cognitive impairment observed in other populations (e.g., older adults). The present study will evaluate GMT's effects in the adult PTSD population. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three treatment conditions - GMT group treatment + Muse meditation device, GMT group treatment w/o Muse device, or a wait-list (in which GMT will be postponed for approximately 21 weeks). The Muse device is a mindfulness meditation aid, anticipated to further enhance the effects of GMT. Knowing other research has focused on the use of GMT within the PSP population (Public Safety Personnel; e.g., police, firefighters, military, paramedics, etc.), this study will focus on two other groups of participants: non-PSP "civilians" with PTSD (stemming from any type of traumatic event), and frontline healthcare workers with PTSD related to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic (e.g., physicians, nurses, respiratory therapists, personal support workers, cleaners, etc.). Due to the pandemic, this study will have two streams: one online stream (i.e., all activities completed virtually or digitally, n=75), and then, once in-person research restrictions have lifted, a second stream that will involve in-person assessments, treatment, and pre/post fMRI scans (functional magnetic resonance imaging; n=75). Content of assessment and treatment materials will be the same for both streams, with the exception of the fMRI scans.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is a randomized control trial investigating GMT as an intervention for PTSD-related cognitive impairment/dysfunction. Participants will be randomized to one of three conditions: GMT + mindfulness meditation aid; GMT (without mindfulness meditation aid); or wait-list.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Sustained Attention to Response Task (SART) scores from baseline to post-treatment assessment
primary_outcome.description: A computer-based go/no-go task that requires participants to withhold behavioral response to a single, infrequent target presented amidst a background of frequent non-targets. This task assesses inattentiveness, impulsivity, sustained attention, and vigilance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Sustained Attention to Response Task (SART) scores from post-treatment to 3-month follow-up assessment
primary_outcome.description: A computer-based go/no-go task that requires participants to withhold behavioral response to a single, infrequent target presented amidst a background of frequent non-targets. This task assesses inattentiveness, impulsivity, sustained attention, and vigilance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in score on Spatial Planning task (part of Cambridge Brain Science's online battery) from baseline to post-treatment assessment.
primary_outcome.description: Assesses the participant's ability to act with forethought, and sequence behaviour in an orderly fashion to reach specific goals (i.e., executive functioning). Similar to the Tower of London test.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale (DERS) score from baseline to post-treatment assessment
primary_outcome.description: A 36-item self-report measure that assesses difficulties with emotion regulation across six domains. A total score is derived by summing all the items - ranging from 36 to 180. Higher scores indicate greater dysfunction in emotion regulation.

arm_group.description: Participants in this arm will attend 9 weekly, 2-hour group GMT appointments. These participants will also use the Muse headband (a mindfulness meditation device) in combination with the Myndlift app to achieve at-home neurofeedback for a few minutes before each session.
Participants in this arm will attend 9 weekly, 2-hour group GMT appointments (without use of Muse/Myndlift).
Participants in this arm will receive no treatment for approximately 21 weeks (at which point, they will be offered GMT).

intervention.description: GMT is a structured, short-term cognitive remediation program with an emphasis on mindfulness and practice in planning and completion of goal-oriented behaviours. The main objective of GMT is to help participants regain executive control in order to better define goals and monitor performance in achieving them. Sessions include instructional material, interactive tasks, discussion of patients' real-life deficits, and homework assignments. Mindfulness meditation is also incorporated for the purpose of developing the skill of bringing one's mind to the present to monitor ongoing behaviour, goal states, and the relationship between them, and for the development of attentional control. The program further incorporates real-life examples to illustrate goal attainment failures and successes, as well as in-session practice of complex tasks that mimic real-life tasks - an issue for individuals with executive function deficits (e.g., planning and set-shifting tasks).

The Muse headband is a research-grade EEG device that passively senses brain activity and translates it into auditory & visual feedback, guiding the user to a state of greater calm & focus. Using this in combination with the Myndlift app will allow study researchers to conduct at-home neurofeedback with participants in an effort to enhance the benefit of GMT.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fits into one of the occupational groups being investigated by this study (i.e., front-line healthcare workers impacted by the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic ; non-Personal Safety Personnel occupations)
- diagnosis of PTSD as determined by our baseline assessment
- For online stream: has access to a computer with a working microphone and camera (or webcam), reliable access to a secure internet connection, and access to a quiet, private space for the assessments and group sessions.
- Ability to provide informed consent
- Fluency in written and spoken English
Exclusion Criteria:
- For in-person (fMRI) stream: any implants, conditions, etc. that do not comply with 7T (Tesla) fMRI research safety standards (e.g., pacemaker, pregnancy/possible pregnancy)
For both in-person and online streams:
- history of significant head injury/lengthy loss of consciousness (e.g., a Glasgow Coma Scale Score < 15 at the time of incident as assessed retrospectively by participant)
- significant untreated medical illness
- history of neurological or neurodevelopmental disorder
- history of any pervasive developmental disorder
- any medical disorder known to adversely affect cognition within the last 12 months
- lifetime bipolar or psychotic disorder
- alcohol/substance abuse or dependence within the last 3 months
- extensive narcotic use (e.g., fentanyl, oxycodone, etc.), use of anti-cholinergics, anti-psychotics, psychostimulants, or benzodiazepines
- ECT (electroconvulsive therapy) within the last 12 months
- current participation in counselling more extensive than supportive therapy (e.g., exposure therapy, CBT/Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, EMDR/Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing)
- significant dissociative disorder (as determined by our baseline assessment)
- suicide attempt in last 6 months
